Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s 1968 Night of the Living Dead spawned the full-feature zombie craze in the 1970s, including popular theatrical classics such as The Living Dead at the Manchester Morgue, Zombie, Dawn of the Dead and The Return of the Living Dead.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, the crew are found in an area with spikes with feeding tubes going all throughout the place and into the crew members themselves. It's clear that they haven't eaten for a long time and this makes them wild as they kill every miner who tries to remove the tubes to free them. Nothing makes sense with the story and worst

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to My Life To Live by Godard or Biancaneve by Cipriani and Ruggero Deodato. However, it depicts in a “correct” way the struggle of a poor community against the system.
